trigger: Tyrosine kinase and cAMP - dependent protein kinase activities in <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - activated human B lymphocytes .
In vitro , human B lymphocytes undergo long-term proliferation when activated through <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a protein expressed on their cell surface .
The nature of <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent signals in proliferating fresh human Epstein-Barr virus - negative B lymphocytes is currently unknown .
In this study , a <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent B cell culture system was used to examine the role of different signal transduction elements .
Protein kinase C ( PKC ) depletion generated by a long-term phorbol 12 myristate 13-acetate treatment had weak effects on proliferation .
Rather , tyrosine phosphorylation was shown to be directly involved in mediating <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent signals .

The use of the protein tyrosine kinase ( PTK ) - specific inhibitor herbimycin A dramatically decreased cellular proliferation without altering the activity of the human immunodeficiency virus-1 long terminal repeat ( HIV-1 LTR ) , a promoter largely dependent on the binding of nuclear factor kappa B ( NF - kappa B ) .
In contrast , the cAMP - dependent protein kinase specific inhibitor H-89 totally inhibited HIV-1 LTR activity at a concentration as low as 100 nM without affecting cellular proliferation .

Electrophoretic mobility shift assay ( EMSA ) and supershift assay using an NF-kappa B binding sequence from the kappa light chain as a probe , revealed that both <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> RelA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were present in <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - stimulated B cells .
While PKC depletion did not alter the NF-kappa B level , treatment of B lymphocytes with H-89 or herbimycin A provoked a decrease in the NF-kappa B level .
These observations establish the importance of different signal transducing pathways leading to <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation of B lymphocytes .
